(A) That you legally/medically lacked the capacity to provide informed consent & make decisions on your own accord

(B) That your parents, other next of kin, and the medical staff involved somehow are not culpable

(C) That your ex-girlfriend was in control of your decisions fully via duress and you had no say over what you did.

I didn't hear any evidence of those things in your post. On the contrary, I'm reading that the culpability is all yours. "My ex-gf told me to do a thing, so I naively did it" isn't going to cut it mate.

You can regret your decisions all you like, but at some point you have to accept that they're your decisions. It doesn't matter who suggested a thing to you if you took that suggestion and ran with it of your own free will. At a certain point you have to accept that you're a freak because YOU made yourself that way.

If you were under 18, you might have some luck in suing the medical practice who undertook the transition but that too really depends. I don't think you have a hope in hell of successfully suing your ex, but take it too a lawyer near you and see what they say.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28045101
>How is it possible to be so aware of your problems and still not do anything about it?
Because you've decided you enjoy having your problems more than you enjoy fixing them.
It's the same for everyone.
People who complain about having no girlfriend will prefer being socially reluctant, worrying about offending them, having all the feelings that keep them isolated, and agreeing with the isolation.
A lot of people SAY they want to change their situation, but what they really mean is "My situation sucks and it feels bad, and I wish to resolve this feeling, WITHOUT disagreeing with or changing any of the feelings I currently have."
And since the feelings they currently have are what put them in that situation, they honestly don't want to fix their situation, they just want to complain about the path they've chosen.
>HOW? How is that possible?
Because you live a life based on fear and regret.
Fear and regret are not emotions that inspire you.
Since you're used to having fear and regret, you decide to keep having problems, so that you can keep having the fear and regret that you like.
If you wanted to, you'd stop having a fear and regret mindset, and instead have a "Let's make the most of what we still have" mindset.
You clearly don't want to do this. So thus you clearly don't want to change.

Tl;dr: Because you choose to have your problems as you'd prefer to feel sad about them than not.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28045135
>So then what exactly motivates people to change?
Much like you, they dislike their current situation.
Or they anticipate greater joy in a different situation.
But, unlike you, they aren't addicted to their current situation. Their desire to stay the same, to keep feeling bad, to maintain their current habits, isn't as strong.
And when your desire to have different habits > your desire to maintain your current ones, you change.
>Am I just an inherently retarded person?
No, you're just in denial about what you want.
> Why don't I want to engage in it?
Because you honestly like and prefer the emotions of fear and regret, and doing what you're doing gets you more fear and regret.
>if I didn't want to I wouldn't complain about it and accept it.
Fear and regret feel bad, brosef. It's normal to express those bad feelings.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28045135
You know those motivational progress videos you get from your typical highschooler from skinny/fat to fit? The one common theme each of them had was being made fun of, which led them to being insecure.

Very often, unnecessary pain and suffering is the motivation. David Goggins hated himself and was insecure. The only way to truly change is if you want something badly like air. From a psychological standpoint and my own experience of attempting to change, you cannot casually want it as if it was something trivial, it needs to be like "If I can't have this then I'm better of dead" level.

If you want motivation, the first thing you must first endure is being tormented in your life. You know what to do, but you just don't want it badly enough because you're not insecure or self-loathing enough, you haven't experienced hell in your life. Sometimes it's necessary to feel insecure (if you're morbidly obese) and sometimes it isn't. If you just semi-want it, then you will put semi-effort.

George Carlin said it best: if you want motivation, get beaten by a golf club in the back of your head multiple times.

im not very good at giving advice, all i can offer is that half the game is entirely mental, and the other half is all the stereotypical advice about improving your physical appearance, getting fit, not eating slop and whatnot that you can read in a million different other places.
mentally, you have to expunge any sort of self deprecating tendencies that gnaw at the back of your mind. i am aware of my flaws and shortcomings and i don't delude myself, but they're compartmentalized neatly away and don't bleed into my interactions with other people. at no point in time do i ever really feel sorry for myself or view any facet of my identity with any negativity. im entirely self assured in myself and that naturally reflects itself in your interactions with others and they perceive that as well. i own anything i say, like, do, aspire for, etc. even offhandedly referring to ur past self as a hikki here suggests that term is incorporated at least in part into ur self image.
if someone doesn't vibe with that, fuck em, i discard that interaction entirely and start fresh with someone new and don't let it weigh on me. depending on how the other person presents themselves i might let different parts of my personality shine through, but i won't present as something entirely different from who i am or change myself to please others. even if i'm not a ripped billionaire, i still have the mindset that i'm filtering people for MY circle and not the other way around.
idk this was probably all babble
basically acknowledge ur shortcomings, tuck them neatly away, be kind to yourself in mind and body, there's a spectrum between thinking you're vermin and thinking you're a god where you can recognize opportunities for improvement while still presenting outwardly as confident and self-assured to others. finding the right balance will make the physical improvements come more easily. life is boring as fuck, may as well see what you're capable of.

9/10 is the highest any real person can ever be. These are very rare, and even more rarely seen in public. As an example George Clooney has a facial symmetry of 94.2% scrapping him in just bearly as a 9/10. 9/10s with higher symmetry tend to be elusive, they don't have an easy life.

Brat Pitt on the other hand has a facial symmetry of 90.5% making him an 8/10. Essentially all 8/10s work in promotions of some kind and at an elite level, be it modelling, acting, music, whatever.

Andrew Tate has a facial symmetry of below 70% making him a 6/10.

Another less technical way to look at it for quick reference for your average, everyday experience is this. The average person is a 5/10. A degree more attractive than the average is a 6/10. A degree above them a 7/10 and so forth. A degree lower is a 4/10, a degree below that a 3/10 and so forth. Each degree is an exponential step in symmetry up or down. That "very attractive chick" you saw on the street was statistically most likely a 5/10 or 6/10.

Hi anon. I too have a very high tolerance to mind altering substances. I can take 8 Valium and hardly feel a thing. It’s supposed to be a dangerous dose not recommended for anyone but it just doesn’t affect me.
I was severely abused as a teenager and I think that changed my brain chemistry somehow so I have a very high tolerance for physical and emotional pain and chemical substances. Just my theory.
Unfortunately it also means I can take drug use to extremes and get blind drunk but not fall over/pass out. Also it means that when I do self-destructive behaviour it is extreme - otherwise it doesn’t scratch that itch for me. These are very very bad outcomes.
What works is firstly realising that I cannot or rather do not want to do anything in moderation and that is unhealthy. I want control and knowledge of whatever situation me and my loved ones are in. Again, not good, but needs to be understood. I understand i will default to self-sabotage in relationships, health and finances. This took me decades to work out.
So the answer is to channel my extreme nature into fitness and discipline and realise that there are things beyond my control and to let go of trying to influence those things. This includes other people and the world around me.
Turn to Christ. Wear yourself out with physical activity. Surrender your SM desire to influence anything beyond yourself.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Anon I went to therapy for a few months for your exact problem and what i learned more than anything is the basic idea of expanding your comfort zone.
Right now your comfort zone is tiny, it's maybe so small you only feel comfortable when alone, and you can only really semi-confidently do simple tasks in public like getting gas or getting groceries or whatever.
You need to expand your comfort zone, slowly. For me, it took looking at the things in my daily life that give me anxiety, and doing the ones I was able to do. Over time, through exposure, that anxiety lessens, your comfort zone expands, and you can start to tackle the things that right now seem too big abd too scary for you.
For me, I was unable to cook or watch tv when my family was home. I recognized these things, and worked to try tackling them, and they got easier. Doing that made me a bit more comfortable expressing myself (through what I choose to watch) and not worrying about being judged (from what I choose to eat and how I prepare it). Working on tackling those seemingly small things make the big things that much easier.
But I don't know much, I'm still struggling not to be an agoraphobic college dropout just like you

I've been reading "how to make friends and influence people", and it says a TON about this subject, about how being corrected wounds your pride. I recommend it. It hasn't said anything about how to alleviate your own feelings, but it's clear that even the greatest people feel the way you do. It's normal to be wrong, and it's normal to feel bad about it. If you were right only 55% of the time you'd make a million dollars a day. Dale Carnegie talked to a very successful person that reviewed all the good and bad things he did every week, and it almost always made him feel perfectly awful.

You're a hero for even admitting that you're wrong, because MOST people don't make it that far, they'd rather make excuses. It means you're on the path of self-improvement. You're still going to feel bad for the next few hours or days, but it's going to pass. Just have some ice cream in the meantime.

posts.sub: Having adhd sucks sometimes
posts.com: I’ve always been that person who talks too much, can’t sit in a chair normally, gets really excited about certain things, and loses everything (fucking everything) but it wasn’t until recently that I actually got diagnosed with adhd mostly because I’m a woman and I’ve been told we are better at masking or something. I never really set aside these differences from other people as adhd I was always just told I was “quirky” or something but now that I know what to call it it’s digging up a lot of past memories and current issues. When I was younger I was bullied so hard for being a “spaz” which made me internalize my anger and start self harming. Now that I’m older the biggest issue I face is being told to calm down when I’m really excited about something. This may not seem like a big deal but when I’m excited to talk about something it feels like it’s the only time that my brain works in a straight line and I still haven’t quite mastered the act of knowing when someone doesn’t give a fuck. I just want to nerd out on whatever it be. (usually biology related) When someone tells me to calm down or relax it brings me back to those days of being called a spaz and it hurts it really fucking hurts. It reminds me that I’m not like everyone else and it makes me feel like my passions are invalidated. Sometimes people go as far as to say things like “god do you ever shut up” and that hurts double. I’m getting to the point again where I’m just gonna start internalizing shit and nobody is ever gonna hear from me again. This sucks because I’ve always been a massive extrovert and telling people about my passions is my love language. I wish that people could just understand that and understand me but they don’t and they never will. How do I mask this better so that I won’t become a total shut in when one more person tells me to relax during my rant about a new species I learned about. I just wish they could share my excitement, really

The issue here is, you AREN'T both cool with it - he thinks something is cheating, or it's something he's uncomfortable with. Your best option is to talk it out with him but go in accepting that maybe he won't budge on the topic, and you'll have to respect his boundary or break up.

Therapy only works if you are willing to make a change. You are not supposed to go there and be "fixed" or turn into someone you are not. As others have said, therapy works best when you approach it as a way of having assessment on how to deal with specific situations in your life that trouble you. Get a therapist that's honest an open with you , someone who doesn't limit the way you speak and who allows you to question him on his methods. Also if a therapist tells you that he doesn't like having his patients for too long then it's a green flag because it means he/she will focus on getting you out of the hole instead of milking you.

posts.com: I used to lucid dream a lot when I was younger. The two things that helped me were the following: 1. writing down my dreams in a journal after waking up 2. Had the habit of asking myself if I'm dreaming while I'm awake. Randomly throughout the day, when I remember to, I would look at my wrist and ask myself I'm dreaming. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28044611
By understanding the shape of the void. Tracing your mind against the full extent of the damage—when it happened, how it happened, why it happened, etc. You will need to reflect on the craters in your soul, how it affected you, and why you reacted in the ways which you have. This will in turn help you better understand yourself.
Next step is to accept yourself, and ultimately, forgive yourself. The goal is to nurture and emotionally validate yourself and raise the parts of you that your parent neglected to raise for whatever reason (Chances are, there was no particular intention against you. Any more than you fully intend to hurt others yourself. Mom was merely damaged and passed on damage to you, unconsciously).

You have the gift of self-awareness however. It is your calling to break the cycle. You can do this by daring to be your own parent, the kind your child-self needed. You can embody the very thing that will fill the void; self-love, self-respect, self-forgiving, self-understanding.

You can do it OP. Its going to be hard, but the pay-off is more than worth it. Conquering the now-demon that was once your inner-child bestows untold clarity and wisdom. The end result is the ‘good ending’ + more. You find self security and peace and power within yourself you didn’t know you even had. Keep going dude, I believe in you!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28041222

>> Introverts can open up and become sociable,

You're confusing social anxiety with introvert. Being an introvert doesn't mean you aren't sociable or "closed".

Similarly, extroverted doesn't have anything to do with being obnoxious or attention seeking.

Neither can cease being what they are, they're core personality traits. They are fixed for life.

Everyone changes and develops over time, not just between certain years but throughout their entire life. That's a natural progression of growth, it isn't what we're talking about here.

What we're talking about is OPs fantasies. This kind of thing;

Become a 6'4" thin woman with large breasts and a lisp. She grew up rich on the right side of town and was popular throughout high school. She makes 6 figures cleaning cages at an animal shelter a couple of hours a week. She enjoys polo, margaritas and has a weakness for latina men. She dreams of one day being a singer. She swam throughout high school and keeps it up in adulthood for exercise.

Now become a 5'9" black man who grew up on the wrong side of the tracks. He slings dope because he never had opportunities in life. His brother got murdered by the rival gang last year so you're out for revenge.

That's what we're talking about here. It's a type of dysmorphia common to trauma victims where they try to deal with the pain by becoming someone else. Think of any character from a movie or a video game, now imagine trying to become that person, not become LIKE that person, but actually become them with all of their memories, personality traits, desires, etc. Like imagine trying to become Luke Skywalker or James Bond, and act like you're literally fighting a war against the federation, or you're literally a British spy when in reality you're a dumpy 19 year old with no prospects.

OP has realised after trying that he can't become someone else and he wants to know how to deal with not being able to become someone other than he is.

posts.sub: is family life worth it
posts.com:
My view of marriage and family life is growing increasingly cynical. I won't deny the reality that there are real benefits in being surrounded by positive, supportive people nor do will I deny the basic human need for company. The issue is that modern life makes independence far more viable whilst also creating huge liabilities for actual families.

I have nearly no positive examples of marriage in my (24m) life. Around me I see husbands that have become cold and uncaring and wives with no resilience or patience. Our capsized economy means that kids cannot possibly get the parental attention they need since both parents need to work; I doubt it's a coincidence that the only happy family I know is filthy rich.

These issues reflect flaws in individuals, not marriage itself - but the evidence around me says otherwise.

My basic impression is that the stress of family life is enough to turn ~80% of good people bad or at least break them down a little The costs-vs-benefit shifted once the economics of supporting a child become so shit whilst technology made it viable for somebody to survive on their own.

I try to be positive, I know that "it's different once you meet that special girl," but part of me thinks it's all just a cope for how helpless people are on their own. I would appreciate if any older, wiser anons could offer any thoughts/advice, especially those who are/were married.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28043016
You're confusing your thoughts anon. You're wondering if having a family - children - is worth it, not if getting married is worth it. And you already laid it out: If you want children, you need to be in the money. You're still very young, so work on getting that money. My oldest brother went from being a security guard at 28, went to one of those online university things for systems networking, now he makes a little over six figures and bought a home in the suburbs last year. He's got a fiance and a son and he's very happy since he works from home for about six hours.

>>28043995
Also things I'd recommend:
>if you can put 20% down do it
>get a third party home inspector and don't get the one that your realtor recommends
>really take the time to think if this is the right house or now. do multiple house tours if you need to. I regret rushing into the buying frenzy last year. with today's market you'll probably be holding onto this property for at least 5-10 years so make sure it's the right one
>most banks should allow you to contribute more to your monthly payment which I'd highly recommend
>factor in closing costs, this could be anywhere from $3k to over $10k depending on a wide range of factors
>factor in emergency savings you'll need once you actually move in. if you don't have money for a plumbing, roof, or HVAC issue that costs $10k you're gonna be in trouble
>shop around for different contractors and get multiple quotes before deciding to actually use one's services
>look into any rebate programs your state has - mine for example has a ton for energy savings rebates and it saved me thousands for new insulation and will do the same for new windows for example
>get ready for a lot of yard work. try to do as many things as you possibly can on your own in order to save money
Personally I also regret not getting a garage as I live in a state that gets some snow, and garages also help with the home value and reselling potential. Oh well

It's a lot to think about it. It doesn't mean you can't do it. You can buy a cheaper, more affordable house like I did. You can also get a condo. The only drawbacks with condos are the potential for being really close to your neighbors (if it's those apartment style condos then you're basically in an apartment again) as well as the HOA fees. posts.sub: Reasons to live?
posts.com:
TLDR I’m not looking for a way out but legitimately looking for something to hold on to

> Awful job that doesn’t pay me enough to live, all the other jobs I can manage to get pay more but are further away so there’s no actual financial gain
> Passion for art and music, tried to make it a career but that flopped
> Tried just making art and music for personal fulfillment but it’s a diminishing return and I’ve lost motivation + I hate the “scene” politics of brown nosing and people trying to suck me into their hustle grindset
> Going to college for something I’m good at but not super passionate about. Constantly questioning whether I’d be doing clients a disservice by not being very devoted to the work
> Family’s a bunch of shitheads who refuse to change, I love them but I do not legitimately like them and most piss me off within 5 minutes
> Old friends grew distant starting families/careers and don’t bother keeping in touch, worked on being more social but new friends are superficial and unreliable
> Dating pool mostly consists of turbo normies with bland personalities, all the other girls are FUBAR with daddy issues that they like to hide from me until I let my guard down
> Started eating healthier but it’s been gradually getting harder to fit in my budget. Tried to go with more canned food to save money and can barely stomach the preservatives
> Started exercising and am more fit but little effect on mood
> Started going on hikes and camping trips, but mostly reminded of how lonely I am. Plus gas prices have made that unaffordable.
> No interest in having children, mother has progressive neurological degeneration and I’m showing early signs of having it too
> All signs point to clinical depression but I refuse to take any more pills after the bullshit experiences I’ve had.

posts.sub: Cutting down drinking
posts.com:
How the FUCK do I stop my daily drinking habit? Ever since corona lockdowns I've probably drank an average of 5 days every week for the last three years.
I don't want to teetotal since I'd still like to enjoy alcohol at social events and have my cold beer + chicken fried on Friday nights, but I know I need to stop drinking every day because it's killing my body and mind slowly and erasing my ability to naturally cope with stress. Not to mention I can't fall asleep/stay asleep anymore without a few drinks in me, which is really bad.
I'm on day 2 of a self-imposed 5 day "break" and I'm already craving a drink. How the fuck do I maintain my willpower?

I am busy, I run a startup that burns six figures monthly, I guarantee I'm busier than you, I'm making this thread while on a conference call. It's this state of constant stress to produce results + the work being so boring (lots of emails, lots of presentations, lots of just staring at computer code while debugging) and long (12-14 hour days are my norm) that makes me want to "unwind" with a drink. posts.com:
What helped me cut down was moving on to expensive craft beer. Instead of necking six packs of piss water to get drunk fast, I got hooked on constant novelty and the extra cost gave me just enough pain to not buy too much. I would never drink the same beer twice in a night.

Over time, I became a beer snob and stopped being able to enjoy the cheap shit I used to buy. I gradually just drank less and less as I started viewing the beers as more of a luxury for special occasions. I still enjoy a good drink on special occasions, but my fridge is no longer permanently stocked with beers.

What keeps me from getting back into it is thinking of the cost of it, as well as being such a beer snob that I can't be tempted by the thought of a six pack any more. I NEED it to be a Basedboy Stout or I'm not interested.

is how you believe a 29 year old act based on something objective that you know? was it based upon some subjective notion?

which is a long-winded way to ask: How is a 29-year-old supposed to act?

of course, this is a rhetorical question because there's no objective answer. A lots of people will say they have an object of answer, but it's actually subjective based on their beliefs, morals and experiences.

in my perception of your question, I think that it's easy to remember your own perception and compared to your current perception and feel like you haven't changed. it's easy to feel like you're at the same person you've always been because you're still experiencing the world from your perception.

I think what's more important is to look at yourself and figure out what specifically you want to change and work towards specific objective and obtainable goals.

because if you chase something that is so vague as to what you said, you will never be satisfied with the outcome.

I'm a stem major with a music minor. I'm go to a neuroscience journal club on Wednesdays. I don't really have time to go out, anyway, because my time gets filled by studying, my job, working out, practicing my instrument, and I have to have time to myself or else I get overwhelmed.
I also don't really people in general. I don't know if I really want friends or if I just need human interaction.
Anyway. How does an introverted, goal-oriented college sophomore stop feeling depressed?
lmao this is so cringe

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28043467
socializing at college is both easier and harder than in highschool, but still infinitely easier than when you are out of school. what you can do:
>join clubs, and go to their events
>join study groups, or make them, for your classes (particularly upper div classes, gen ed need not apply)
>hang out in the same places regularly, particularly your department
>learn how to casually say "hey, we should hang out, let me give you my number/whats your insta?"
>say yes
>study less at home than you do on campus
note, that all of these require you to actually put a modicum of effort in.

posts.com:
i'm very conscious of my loneliness between new year's and valentine's day but its basically entirely self-inflicted and i don't feel a particularly strong desire to change that.
im grotesquely narcissistic and i take great care never to incorporate anything ordinary, popular, mainstream, conventional into my identity and my personality. i'll let myself watch shit like the office or play call of duty with my friends or listen to top 40 music but i would never dream of letting these things be my 'favorite' in their respective categories. i feel extreme, debilitating disgust whenever somebody unironically makes disney or marvel a primary part of their identity and its very fulfilling to introduce people to new things and broaden their outlook. i always stand out to people and i'm very personable and accommodating.
it's easy enough to make friends with this mindset, there's a lot of guys online and in-person with good taste and unique interests. it feels like there's an extreme shortage of interesting women though. most girls i knew in college had basically no interests or hobbies beyond hanging out with their friends or listening to some digital slop like the call her daddy podcast.
any truly interesting women i've met IRL are spoken for and closely-guarded and those online are guaranteed to have BPD or some debilitating trauma, not that i'm cut out for long distance relationships anyways.
